sp.p: As I was about to say, I have a little secret I want to impart. You remember I caught Fifteen Thousand Dollars in the Louisiana Lottery and paid off a Nine Hundred Dollar mortgage on that 125 acres we have down in Wilson County, Kansas.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Umph! Umph!

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: You know I promised Aunt Cally, Uncle Rube Fowler, Miss Primly and the other girls, I'd take them abroad.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: And me-

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Of course you, you're here ain't you? Well at first I only figured on going as far as Paris.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: As I stroll along the Boise-de-Boulogne.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: We had a good time in Paris, Eh! Jas?

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Go on Donne-Lui Ce qui est La, Madam? Oh pshaw!

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: That will do how, that will do. As I was saying, I didn't intend to go any further than Paris, but something happened in Paris.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Yes you got arrested for fighting a French man.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: No, no, I mean something important happened
sp.stage: (looks around suspiciously beckons for Jas to come closer. Bus. for Jas)
sp.p: You know Wilson County is the center of the oil industry of Kansas, well the biggest oil well in the County was discovered within the borders of that 125 acres. Our agent sold the 25 acres surrounding the oil well, for a big bunch of money and I received the coin the day before we left Paris, hence the fresh supply of Mazuma.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: After you give me one of them crackers, there's another secret that's been troubling me more than anything else
Why did you leave the Boise-de-Boulogne for the sandy De-Dez?

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Paris is a wonderful place-attractive, luxurious, magnificent who could forget the Palais Royal, Louvre, Luxembourg--

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: And the Bois-de-Boulogne.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: To pick up my narrative--

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: If it don't make any difference to you, would you mind picking up a cracker at the same time?

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: This fresh supply of money gave me an opportunity to gratify my one life long hobby "Astronomy."

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Ras Johnson, you've talked about more funny diseases since you've had money, then any man I've ever seen. Neuritis, Neuroma, Neurosis. Nephritis of the Pedal extremities, Chiropody and now you've got the Hobbyastronomous.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Astronomy isn't a disease, its a science. Astronomy treats of the heavenly bodies. Considered as to their nature, heavenly bodies may be divided into two great classes. Class one: incandescent bodies which shine by their own light. Class two: opaque bodies which are visible only by reflecting the light of some incandescent body in their neighborhood. Now the three fundamental facts which determine the phenomena of Astronomy are: The Globular form of the earth, its diurnal rotation on its axis and its annual revolution around the sun. To represent the position of the stars, astronomers imagine circles on the Celestial sphere, corresponding to the circles of longitude and latitude on the earth. To explain to you longitude and latitude, the Meridian of Greenwich, Celestial meridians and the like, would be a waste of time, but I might be able to interest you----

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: If you'd just show me the photograph of a cracker---

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Now if I should take you at your word and afterward didn't give you the cracker, it's more than likely you would have a serious case of muscular contraction of the oesophagus, in that case, what would you do?

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Say my prayers.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: If you'll agree not to interrupt me for five minutes, I may furnish you with a few of these crackers.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: I'll sign the Armistice.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: As I was saying, I might be able to interest you by stating that I lingered a bit in the rear of the Caravan to-day to try an experiment.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: I thought---

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: But you are not to think at all and by interrupting me, you have broken your agreement on the cracker question.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: I appeal from the decision.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: I'll give you the crackers if you'll just keep still.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Unconditional surrender.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: To resume: I'm going to try an experiment and I know of no better place than here on the Continent where the first authoritative school of astronomy had its birth, I refer to the Alexandrian school. If what I learned of a disciple of this school of astronomy at Cairo, be true, I shall be able to bring about any weather condition I desire which of course will be a great benefit to Kansas. Change day-light to darkness, darkness to moon- light, moon-light to star light and visa versa
Don't interrupt please, my first attempt will be to produce total darkness-

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Ladies and gentlemen, with the kind permission of the audience, Rastus Johnson will smother the sun.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.stage: (Walking down stage two or three steps and fondling gun)
sp.p: I will now bring about a total eclipse. For your benefit, I will explain what an eclipse is. An eclipse is an obstruction of the light of a heavenly body by another, effected either directly by its intervention between the body and the observer, or indirectly by its interception of the source of light which illuminates the body-
You understand, don't you?

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Oh! yes!

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Very well. Of course this being a total eclipse, will be unlike the eclipse of 1928 and 1967.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: When?

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: 1928 and 1967. In these two, the moon's shadow will just graze the pole of the earth.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Excuse me Professor, but ain't this 1905?

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: This is A.D. 1905.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.stage: (Looks intently at Ras, then to audience)
sp.p: Decision reserved until the mental responsibility of the defendant has been established.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: That you are skeptical, does not surprise me at all, but as in all cases where science is concerned, people of your mental calibre, must have an ocular demonstration, and that I shall try to give you by first counteracting the calorific rays of the sun, thereby causing an unusual humidity--

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Further explanation unaccompanied by ocular demonstration will not be tolerated. According to Hoyle, the best proof of the pudding is the eating, so let's taste.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.stage: (Raising gun and pointing upward and off stage in L.2.E.)
sp.p: Stand behind me and observe.-
sp.stage: (Fires gun, the report of which must be very light. Louder reports to follow off stage about ten seconds later, then the gradual lowering of the lights. When about two thirds down, insert colored medium until total darkness. Ras and Jas stand with back to audience Ras produces small pocket lamp which he lights)

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: I'm awful glad you sprung that light, I ain't skeered, but Ha! ha!
I-I you know I jes' naturally when the sun-when the sun say ain't there some way you can use the best part of the sun for your experiment and let me have the rest of it?

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: See!

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Who! What! Where?

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: The stars one by one are peeping from the firmament.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: I wish they wouldn't be so bashful and come right out, no excuse for peeping when there ain't nobody to--

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Ah!
There's Luna also.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Who's loony?

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: The moon
Isn't it beautiful?

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.stage: (Pantomimes to audience that Ras is crazy and conveys the idea that he (Jas) is humoring him by showing great interest, looks intently at the moon and rapturously exclaims)
sp.p: Lovely. Lovely.
Say Ras, you ain't forgot them crackers, have you?

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Wait a minute
sp.stage: (Fires gun, light report as before, followed about five seconds later by loud report off stage. One of the stars takes on the appearance of a comet. The same to be repeated two or three times. Drop must be made transparent and lights worked from behind)
sp.p: Try your gun, but be careful not to fire in the direction of the moon.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: You said try your gun and I presume you mean for me to alter the appearance of one of the stars and I have selected that Luminary
next to Luna so stand back and take note of the experiment.
sp.stage: (Shoots, light report from gun followed immediately by several loud reports off stage. Moon increases in size. Picture in moon. Bus. & etc.)

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: You've made a mess of everything, now I'll be compelled to reverse the present condition.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Say Ras, light that light again.
sp.stage: (Ras produces pocket lamp. Just then, chicken crows off stage)
sp.p: Ras are you going to give me some of them crackers?

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Here, take all of them
sp.stage: (Gives crackers to Jas. Again, the chicken crows, louder and louder this time)

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Rastus Johnson, do you hear that voice calling out in the wilderness?
sp.stage: (Takes light, picks up stone, leaves stage R.2. E. Ras watching, lights come up slowly until full up. Bus. catching chicken. Jas returns with chicken)

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: You've got keen ears, Jasamine Jenkins.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: I'd a knowed that voice in the middle of the Red Sea, Rastus Johnson.

sp.speaker: RASTUS
sp.p: Come we'll depart, Jasmine Jenkins.

sp.speaker: JASAMINE
sp.p: Lead on, we'll follow
sp.stage: (Holding up chicken, follows. Exit to music)
